_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The seating arrangement in the new town: The Buddha sat against the central column facing east
The Saṅgha of mendicants sat against the west wall facing east
The Mallas of Pāvā sat against the east wall facing west
The arguments and disputes among the Jai: The Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta passed away at Pāvā
The Jain ascetics split into two factions
They wounded each other with barbed words
The Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta's white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics
The qualities of the Buddha's teaching a: Proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha
The benefits of reciting the Buddha's te: The spiritual path may last for a long time
For the welfare and happiness of the people
For the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans
Teachings grouped by one [dn33:1.7.9.0]: ‘All sentient beings are sustained by food.’
‘All sentient beings are sustained by conditions.’
Teachings grouped by two [dn33:1.9.0]: Name and form
Ignorance and craving for continued existence
Views favoring continued existence and views favoring ending existence
Lack of conscience and prudence
Conscience and prudence
Being hard to admonish and having bad friends
Being easy to admonish and having good friends
Skill in offenses and skill in rehabilitation from offenses
Skill in meditative attainments and skill in emerging from those attainments
Skill in the elements and skill in attention
Skill in the sense fields and skill in dependent origination
Skill in what is possible and skill in what is impossible
Integrity and scrupulousness
Patience and gentleness
Friendliness and hospitality
Harmlessness and purity
Lack of mindfulness and lack of situational awareness
Mindfulness and situational awareness
Not guarding the sense doors and eating too much
Guarding the sense doors and moderation in eating
The power of reflection and the power of development
The power of mindfulness and the power of immersion
Serenity and discernment
The foundation of serenity and the foundation of exertion
Exertion, and not being distracted
Failure in ethics and failure in view
Accomplishment in ethics and accomplishment in view
Purification of ethics and purification of view
Purification of view and making an effort in line with that view
Inspiration, and making a suitable effort when inspired by inspiring places
To never be content with skillful qualities, and to never stop trying
Knowledge and freedom
Knowledge of ending and knowledge of non-arising
Teachings grouped by three that have bee: Three unskillful roots: greed, hate, and delusion.
Three skillful roots: non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion.
Three ways of performing bad conduct: by body, speech, and mind.
Three ways of performing good conduct: by body, speech, and mind.
Three unskillful thoughts: sensuality, malice, and cruelty.
Three skillful thoughts: renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.
Three unskillful intentions: sensuality, malice, and cruelty.
Three skillful intentions: renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.
Three unskillful perceptions: sensuality, malice, and cruelty.
Three skillful perceptions: renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.
Three unskillful elements: sensuality, malice, and cruelty.
Three skillful elements: renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.
Another three elements: sensuality, form, and formlessness.
Another three elements: form, formlessness, and cessation.
Another three elements: lower, middle, and higher.
Three cravings: for sensual pleasures, to continue existence, and to end existence.
Another three cravings: sensuality, form, and formlessness.
Another three cravings: form, formlessness, and cessation.
Three fetters: identity view, doubt, and misapprehension of precepts and observances.
Three defilements: sensuality, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.
Three realms of existence: sensual, form, and formless.
Three searches: for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path.
Three kinds of discrimination: ‘I’m better’, ‘I’m equal’, and ‘I’m worse’.
Three periods: past, future, and present.
Three extremes: identity, the origin of identity, and the cessation of identity.
Three feelings: pleasure, pain, and neutral.
Three forms of suffering: the suffering inherent in painful feeling, the suffering inherent in conditions, and the suffering inherent in perishing.
Three heaps: inevitability regarding the wrong way, inevitability regarding the right way, and lack of inevitability.
Three darknesses: one is doubtful, uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence about the past, future, and present.
Three things a Realized One need not hide: behavior by way of body, speech, and mind.
Three possessions: greed, hate, and delusion.
Three fires: greed, hate, and delusion.
Another three fires: a fire for those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, a fire for householders, and a fire for those worthy of a religious donation.
A threefold classification of the physical: visible and resistant, invisible and resistant, and invisible and non-resistant.
Three choices: good choices, bad choices, and imperturbable choices.
Three individuals: a trainee, an adept, and one who is neither a trainee nor an adept.
Three seniors: a senior by birth, a senior in the teaching, and a senior by convention.
Three grounds for making merit: giving, ethical conduct, and meditation.
Three grounds for accusations: what is seen, heard, and suspected.
Three kinds of sensual rebirth: present, creating, and created by others.
Three kinds of pleasant rebirth: dwelling in pleasure, drenched with pleasure and inspired, drenched with pleasure and content.
Three kinds of wisdom: trainee, adept, and neither trainee nor adept.
Another three kinds of wisdom: produced by thought, learning, and meditation.
Three weapons: learning, seclusion, and wisdom.
Three faculties: understanding that one’s enlightenment is imminent, enlightenment, and one who is enlightened.
Three eyes: the eye of the flesh, the eye of clairvoyance, and the eye of wisdom.
Three trainings: in higher ethics, higher mind, and higher wisdom.
Three kinds of development: physical endurance, the mind, and wisdom.
Three unsurpassable things: seeing, practice, and freedom.
Three kinds of immersion: with placing the mind and keeping it connected, without placing the mind but keeping it connected, without placing the mind or keeping it connected.
Another three kinds of immersion: emptiness, signless, and undirected.
Three purities: purity of body, speech, and mind.
Three kinds of sagacity: sagacity of body, speech, and mind.
Three skills: progress, regress, and means.
Three vanities: health, youth, and life.
Three ways of putting something in charge: oneself, the world, or the teaching.
Three topics of discussion: past, future, and present.
Three knowledges: recollection of past lives, knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings, and knowledge of the ending of defilements.
Three meditative abidings: the meditation of the gods, the meditation of Brahmā, and the meditation of the noble ones.
Three demonstrations: psychic power, revealing, and instructional.
Four things to be realized [dn33:1.11.0]: Passing away and rebirth of sentient beings
Four detachments [dn33:1.11.0]: Detachment from the bonds of sensuality
Detachment from the bonds of desire for rebirth
Detachment from the bonds of views
Detachment from the bonds of ignorance
Four ties [dn33:1.11.0]: Personal ties to misapprehension of precepts and observances
Personal ties to the insistence that this is the only truth
Four kinds of grasping [dn33:1.11.0]: Grasping at theories of a self
Four kinds of reproduction [dn33:1.11.0]: Reproduction for creatures born from an egg
Reproduction for creatures born from a womb
Reproduction for creatures born from moisture
Four kinds of conception [dn33:1.11.0]: Unaware when conceived in their mother’s womb
Aware when conceived in their mother’s womb, but unaware as they remain there
Aware when conceived in their mother’s womb, aware as they remain there, but unaware as they emerge
Aware when conceived in their mother’s womb, aware as they remain there, and aware as they emerge
Four kinds of reincarnation [dn33:1.11.0: Reincarnation where only one’s own intention is effective, not that of others
Reincarnation where only the intention of others is effective, not one’s own
Reincarnation where both one’s own and others’ intentions are effective
Reincarnation where neither one’s own nor others’ intentions are effective
Four ways of purifying a religious donat: Religious donation that’s purified by the giver, not the recipient
Religious donation that’s purified by the recipient, not the giver
Religious donation that’s purified by neither the giver nor the recipient
Religious donation that’s purified by both the giver and the recipient
Another four ignoble expressions [dn33:1: Saying you’ve seen something, but you haven’t
Saying you’ve heard something, but you haven’t
Saying you’ve thought something, but you haven’t
Saying you’ve known something, but you haven’t
Saying you haven’t seen something, and you have
Saying you haven’t heard something, and you have
Saying you haven’t thought something, and you have
Saying you haven’t known something, and you have
Another four noble expressions [dn33:1.1: Saying you haven’t seen something, and you haven’t
Saying you haven’t heard something, and you haven’t
Saying you haven’t thought something, and you haven’t
Saying you haven’t known something, and you haven’t
Saying you’ve seen something, and you have
Saying you’ve heard something, and you have
Saying you’ve thought something, and you have
Saying you’ve known something, and you have
Four persons [dn33:1.11.0]: Person who mortifies themselves and others
Person who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others
Another four persons [dn33:1.11.0]: Person who practices to benefit themselves, but not others
Person who practices to benefit others, but not themselves
Person who practices to benefit neither themselves nor others
Person who practices to benefit both themselves and others
The teachings grouped by four that have: Four ways of purifying a religious donation
Six interior sense fields, Six exterior: Six interior sense fields: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
Six exterior sense fields: sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.
Six classes of consciousness: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness.
Six classes of contact: contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
Six classes of feeling: feeling born of contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
Six classes of perception: perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.
Six bodies of intention: intention regarding sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.
Six classes of craving: craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.
Six kinds of disrespect: lack of respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, the training, diligence, and hospitality.
Six kinds of respect: respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, the training, diligence, and hospitality.
Six preoccupations with happiness: preoccupation with a sight, sound, smell, taste, touch, or thought that’s a basis for happiness.
Six preoccupations with sadness: preoccupation with a sight, sound, smell, taste, touch, or thought that’s a basis for sadness.
Six preoccupations with equanimity: preoccupation with a sight, sound, smell, taste, touch, or thought that’s a basis for equanimity.
Six warm-hearted qualities: bodily kindness, verbal kindness, mental kindness, sharing possessions, living according to precepts, living according to the noble view.
Six roots of arguments: irritable and hostile, offensive and contemptuous, jealous and stingy, devious and deceitful, wicked desires and wrong view, attached to one's own views.
Six elements: earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.

Six elements of escape: heart’s release by love, heart’s release by compassion, heart’s release by rejoicing, heart’s release by equanimity, signless release of the heart, uprooting of the conceit “I am”.
Six unsurpassable things: seeing, listening, acquisition, training, service, and recollection.
Six topics for recollection: Buddha, teaching, Saṅgha, ethics, generosity, and deities.
Six consistent responses: remaining equanimous, mindful and aware when seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, feeling, or knowing.

Six classes of rebirth: dark class giving rise to a dark result, dark class giving rise to a bright result, dark class giving rise to extinguishment, bright class giving rise to a bright result, bright class giving rise to a dark result, bright class giving rise to extinguishment.
Six perceptions that help penetration: impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation.
Teachings grouped by seven [dn33:2.3.0]: Seven aspects of the teachings of the good persons
Seven persons worthy of a religious donation
Seven principles for the settlement of any disciplinary issues that might arise
Eight liberations [dn33:3.1.0]: Having physical form, they see visions. This is the first liberation.
Not perceiving physical form internally, they see visions externally. This is the second liberation.
They’re focused only on beauty. This is the third liberation.

Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space. This is the fourth liberation.
Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness. This is the fifth liberation.
Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness. This is the sixth liberation.
Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. This is the seventh liberation.
Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling. This is the eighth liberation.
They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
This is the eighth dimension of mastery.
Nine grounds for resentment [dn33:3.2.0]: They are doing wrong to me
They will do wrong to me
They did wrong by someone I love
They are doing wrong by someone I love
They will do wrong by someone I love
They are helping someone I dislike
They will help someone I dislike
Nine methods to get rid of resentment [d: They did wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?
They are doing wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?
They will do wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?
They did wrong by someone I love, but what can I possibly do?
They are doing wrong by someone I love, but what can I possibly do?
They will do wrong by someone I love, but what can I possibly do?
They helped someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?
They are helping someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?
They will help someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?
Nine abodes of sentient beings [dn33:3.2: Human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld
The gods reborn in Brahmā’s Host through the first absorption
The gods who are non-percipient beings
The dimension of neither perception nor non-perception
Nine lost opportunities for spiritual pr: Reborn in one of the long-lived orders of gods
Reborn in the borderlands, among strange barbarian tribes
Reborn in a central country with wrong view and distorted perspective
Reborn in a central country with inability to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said
Reborn in a central country where a Realized One has arisen but doesn't teach the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening
Nine progressive meditations [dn33:3.2.0: Dimension of neither perception nor non-perception
Nine progressive cessations [dn33:3.2.0]: Placing of the mind and keeping it connected
Perception of the dimension of infinite space
Perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness
Perception of the dimension of nothingness
Ten qualities that serve as protector [d: Having good friends, companions, and associates
Being deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions
Loving the teachings and being a delight to converse with
Being content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick
Living with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities
Ten noble abodes [dn33:3.3.0]: Eliminating idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth
